scenarioDescription:
The HD 159868 Exoplanetary System


Overview

HD 159868 is a star with 1.19 times the mass of the Sun, and 2.13 times its radius. It is located 182.16 light years away from the solar system.

HD 159868 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the HD 159868 system


HD 159868 b

HD 159868 b was discovered by the Anglo-Australian Telescope observatory, in 2007-05, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 2.32 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HD 159868 b is 705.324 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HD 159868 b is 13.300 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, HD 159868 b is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.


HD 159868 c

HD 159868 c was discovered by the Anglo-Australian Telescope observatory, in 2012-07, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 1.03 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HD 159868 c is 244.224 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HD 159868 c is 14.000 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, HD 159868 c is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system HD 159868, which contains 2 exoplanets and was discovered by the Anglo-Australian Telescope.
name: HD 159868 - System With 2 Exolanets
